title: 103_hr877
content:
The Act is titled the "National African American Museum Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that the presentation and preservation of African American life, art, history, and culture within the National Park System and other Federal entities are inadequate, restricting the understanding of African Americans' past and struggles for recognition. Public Law 99-511 encouraged support for a commemorative structure within the National Park System or on other Federal lands. The establishment of a national museum dedicated to African American heritage and culture is crucial for promoting understanding and education about their contributions to American society. The current lack of a national institution solely focused on African American life, art, history, or culture within the Smithsonian Institution highlights the need for such a museum. Establishment of the National African American Museum. The National African American Museum is established within the Smithsonian Institution with the purpose of serving as a center for scholarship, hosting exhibits, collecting artifacts, providing education programs, and training museum professionals in African American life, art, history, and culture. The Board of Regents is authorized to plan, design, reconstruct, and renovate the Arts and Industries Building of the Smithsonian Institution to house the National African American Museum. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum is established within the Smithsonian Institution, composed of 23 members including the Secretary and Assistant Secretary of the Smithsonian, as well as 21 individuals appointed by the Board of Regents. Terms of appointment are specified. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum consists of 23 members, with members appointed for 3-year terms that can be renewed. Terms are staggered, with 7 members' terms expiring each year for 3 years. Vacancies do not affect the Board's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum consists of 23 members appointed for 3-year terms. Members serve without pay but receive expenses. The chairperson is elected by majority vote, and meetings are held at least twice a year with a majority needed for a quorum. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum consists of 23 members appointed for 3-year terms. A majority is needed for a quorum to conduct business, but a lesser number can receive information on behalf of the Board. The chairperson may accept voluntary services from a member of the Board. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum consists of 23 members appointed for 3-year terms. A majority is needed for a quorum to conduct business, but a lesser number can receive information on behalf of the Board. The chairperson may accept voluntary services from a member of the Board. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE MUSEUM. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum has the authority to recommend budgets, manage collections, acquire artifacts, and establish policies for the museum. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum has the authority to establish policies for the utilization of collections, programming, education, exhibitions, and research related to African American life and culture. They also have the authority to provide for restoration, preservation, and maintenance of collections, solicit funds, and approve expenditures from the endowment. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum has the authority to approve expenditures from the endowment for any Museum purpose, consult with the Director, establish programs with other African American museums and educational institutions for promoting understanding of African American life, art, history, and culture, and support efforts of other organizations in the same mission. The Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum is responsible for developing cooperative programs and exhibitions, managing collections, training museum professionals, providing research fellowships and internships, adopting bylaws, and reporting annually on acquisitions and displays of African American objects and artifacts. The Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution appoints a Director to manage the Museum, along with 5 employees, without following certain civil service laws. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS.

(1) The term ``Board of Regents'' refers to the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution.
(2) The term ``Board of Trustees'' refers to the Board of Trustees of the National African American Museum.
(3) The term ``Museum'' refers to the National African American Museum.
(4) The term ``Arts and Industries Building'' refers to the building located on the Mall at 900 Jefferson Drive, S.W. in Washington, D.C.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Authorized to be appropriated $5,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and such sums as necessary for the operation and maintenance of the Museum. Amounts appropriated shall be available only for costs directly relating to the Museum's establishment and operation. Attest: DONNALD K. ANDERSON, Clerk.
